channel.title: Posts on Discret Choice Modelling Lesson
channel.description: Recent content in Posts on Discret Choice Modelling Lesson

item.title: Binary Regression with Cross Validation
item.description: Lets try and predict if an individual will earn more than $50K (ABOVE50K) using logistic regression based on demographic variables available in the adult data. In this process, we will: Part I Import the data Estimate binary regression (logit and probit) and check some diagnostics Build logit models and predict on test data Do model diagnostics Part II Create training and test samples Compare the cross-validation results with the regression only results Load the data inputData <- read.

item.title: Exercice Penalty ALLISON
item.description: EXERCISE inspired from Paul Allison : logistic regression using SAS, 2nd Ed. Dans cet exercice une attention particulière est donnée aux erreurs d’interprétations. Pour cela la thèmatique est délibérément lourde et sensible, pour forcer à prendre des précautions avant les conclusions attives. Les données sont décrites dans Allison (2010) Data set consists of 147 death penalty cases in the state of New Jersey. The defendant was convicted of first-degree murder with a recommendation by the prosecutor that a death sentence be imposed.

item.title: Dynamic Documents with RMarkdown
item.description: You will find on this post: Access to a survey of commands useful in dynamic documents generation with RStudio (these commands are compatible with html, pdf, presentation, … output formats) Example of pdf Beamer slides generated with RStudio : pdf To generate these slides locally, you can download and extract this archive zip Description of the archive and explanation can be found in the following sections Project Structure Production of the slides is managed by a master Rmd file.

item.title: ReproducibleResearch
item.description: Reproducible Analysis Typical data analysis workflow looks like this: collect data put it in a file or spreadsheet or database run some analyses, written in various scripts, perhaps saving some intermediate results along the way or maybe always working on the raw data. create some plots or tables of relevant summaries of the data, and then go and write a report about the results in a text editor or word processor.

item.title: eighth lesson
item.description: Welcome to the Eighth lesson - 07/12/2020 9:00 - 12:00 This is the final session devoted to defense of your project I ask you to upload your pdf and eventually .Rmd files on Caseine (see link below) Zoom meeting We will use Zoom. item.title: First Lesson October 1rst 2020
item.description: First Lesson Welcome to the first lesson - 05/10/2020 9:00 - 12:00 Introduction These Introduction slides present: Table of contents Introduction Program Motivations Importance of DCM Course Objectives General Context of Choice analysis Four broad frameworks Sample and Measurement Issues in Model Building R and Tests for Categorical Data Inference for a (Single) Proportion Two-Way Contingency Tables The Odds-Ratio Chi-Squared Tests of Independence Zoom meeting We will use Zoom.
